Ni-Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 catalysts were synthesized via co-precipitation by varying the precipitant dropwise addition time (0, 5, 10, 20 min) to control nucleation and growth dynamics. This parameter critically influences the physicochemical properties of the catalysts, particularly the oxygen storage capacity (OSC) and Ni dispersion. Rapid dropwise addition (0, 5 min) resulted in insufficient lattice distortion, yielding fewer oxygen vacancies and lower oxygen storage capacity. Conversely, overly slow dropwise addition (20 min) led to excessive Ce3 + migration, promoting the Ce covering effect and suppressing Ni0 dispersion. An optimal dropwise addition time (10 min) revealed balanced characteristics with high OSC and superior Ni0 dispersion, leading to improved catalytic activity and stability in the dry reforming of methane. These findings demonstrate that fine-tuning of precipitation kinetics is crucial for optimizing Ce-Ni interfacial phenomena and maximizing catalytic performance. Graphical Abstract Keywords Ni-Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 catalyst Precipitant dropwise addition time Oxygen vacancy Ni redistribution Ce covering effect Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Dry reforming of methane (DRM, CH4 + CO2 ↔ 2CO + 2 H2) is an attractive process because it not only enables the simultaneous removal of two major greenhouse gases but also produces hydrogen, which is emerging as a next-generation energy source [1–4]. The most important task in DRM is the design of catalysts that exhibit high activity, long-term stability, and economic feasibility [5,6]. To address these challenges in the DRM, a variety of materials, experimental parameter adjustments, and advanced technologies have been applied. Nickel is widely applied as an active metal rather than a noble metal because it offers more economical advantages and exhibits superior activity in the DRM [7]. However, Ni-based catalysts become rapidly deactivated due to the coking and sintering of the active metal during the DRM [8]. Therefore, reducible supports such as CeO2 were applied to Ni-based catalysts to enhance their performance. The key role of CeO2 is the high oxygen storage capacity (OSC), which arises from its redox cycle between Ce3+ and Ce4+ [9]. For this reason, CeO2-based catalysts have recently been widely studied [10,11]. Among them, some studies have revealed that Ce-rich catalysts with ZrO2 (e.g., Ni-Ce0.8Zr0.2O2) outperform Zr-rich or non-Zr catalysts in the DRM due to their enhanced dispersion, OSC, and redox properties [12,13]. Due to the comparable ionic radius of Ce4+ and Zr4+, Zr4+ ions can substitute for Ce4+ ions in the CeO2 lattice, inducing a structural defect of the support [14]. This leads to the generation of Ce3+ species and oxygen vacancies, which not only accelerate the redox mechanism of the catalyst but also contribute to the enhanced dispersion of the active metal. According to the previous literature, the preparation method plays a crucial role in influencing the interaction between Ni and the support, as well as the OSC and dispersion of Ni particles [15–17]. In particular, controlling the dropwise addition time of the precipitant during catalyst synthesis can affect both the nucleation and growth rates of the precursor sediment [18,19]. This, in turn, affects not only the physicochemical properties of the catalyst but also its activity and stability in the target reaction. Adjusting the dropwise addition time of the precipitant can lead to the formation of oxygen vacancies, which serve as anchoring sites for the active metal [20]. In reducible metal oxides such as CeO2, the formation of oxygen vacancies induces distortion of the surrounding atomic structure, which generates high-energy active sites on the surface [21]. Oxygen vacancies provide an electron-rich environment, enabling partial electron transfer to Ni nanoparticles and thereby triggering strong metal-support interactions [22]. In addition, the structural distortion associated with these vacancies creates preferential adsorption sites that can lower the energy of metal nanoparticles [23]. As a result, when Ni nanoparticles are highly dispersed via the anchoring effect of oxygen vacancies, they exhibit superior catalytic performance in the DRM reaction. Meanwhile, under reducing conditions, the migration of Ce3+ ions can lead to the so-called “Ce covering effect”, where CeO2 partially covers the active metal on the catalyst surface [24]. This phenomenon may either suppress catalytic activity or strengthen the metal-support interaction, depending on the extent and nature of the coverage. Thus, it is essential to optimize the dropwise addition time of the precipitant to regulate the Ce covering effect and maximize the dispersion of the Ni. While previous studies have investigated the influence of precipitant dropwise addition time on the CeO2 (a single-metal oxide system), reports on mixed oxide systems (Ce0.8Zr0.2O2) remain limited. Despite the limited scope of existing studies, most have simply focused on observing the Ce covering effect, while attempts to regulate or control this effect remain scarce. As the degree of nucleation and nuclei growth may exert unique effects within the mixed oxide matrix, further investigation is necessary. As the Ce coverage effect has pros and cons for the catalytic performance, we attempted to control it by balancing the Ce coverage effect with the Ni dispersion, achieved by controlling the precipitant dropwise time during the co-precipitation method. Herein, we aimed to develop catalysts with enhanced performance in the DRM by controlling the dropwise addition time (0 (Direct), 5, 10, 20 min) of precipitant, thereby tuning the nucleation and growth rates during synthesis. Various characterization methods were employed to investigate the physicochemical features of the catalysts and to observe how these behaviors influence their capability in the DRM. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis The Ce0.8Zr0.2O2-supported Ni catalyst (15 wt%) was synthesized by the co-precipitation method with varying precipitant dropwise addition time (Total dropwise addition time = 0 (Direct), 5 min, 10 min, 20 min). Ni(NO3)2∙6 H2O (97.5 %, Merck), Ce(NO3)3∙6 H2O (99.7 %, Merck), and zirconyl nitrate solution (20 wt% ZrO2 basis, MEL Chemicals) were utilized as the precursors. Each precursor was dissolved in D.I. water at room temperature. After the solution reached 80 °C, 15 wt% KOH solution was injected with a different dropwise addition time, acting as the precipitant. The quantitative amount of KOH aqueous solution was dropwised according to a calculated stoichiometry. The precipitates were digested for 72 h at 80 °C. Then, the precursor sediment was filtered five times with D.I. water. The filtrate was dried in the oven at 120 °C for 12 h, and then calcined in air at 800 °C for 6 h to obtain 15 wt% Ni-Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 powder. Prepared catalysts were labeled as shown in Table 1. 2.2 Characterization Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) analysis was performed to confirm the catalyst composition remained stable under different experimental conditions. A 0.1 g sample was treated with nitric and hydrochloric acids and digested using a microwave digestion system (MDS) for complete dissolution. The digested solution was then diluted with 6 % hydrochloric acid and filtered through a 0.45 μm syringe filter before characterization. The specific surface area and pore characteristics, including volume and size, were analyzed using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 system. In advance of measurement, the catalysts underwent pre-treatment at 200 °C for 6 h under vacuum to eliminate residual impurities. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was applied for surface area, while the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) technique was employed to assess the pore structure. Raman spectra were conducted using an InVia reflex (Renishaw) with the 532 nm excitation line, yielding a resolution of 0.5 cm−1. All samples used for Raman spectra analysis were pre-treated in the same way as for the DRM. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed with reduced samples using a NEXSA (ThermoFisher) and the obtained analysis results were subjected to peak deconvolution using the Casa XPS program. X-ray Diffraction (XRD) patterns for ex-situ reduced samples were analyzed with a EMPYREAN (Panalytical) and a scan was conducted in the 2θ range of 20° to 80°, with a scan rate of 0.02°/s. The crystallite size of Ni0 was calculated using the Scherrer equation. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained with a HF-3300 (Hitachi) instrument. For the ex-situ analysis of all reduced samples, a passivation process was carried out after reduction with a 10 % H2/N2 flow at 800 °C for 3 h and exposing the samples to a 2 % O2/N2 flow at room temperature for 6 h. These powders were suspended in ethanol by sequential two-step ultrasonication and then dropped onto a grid. In-situ XRD analysis was performed using SmartLab (Rigaku). The scanning was conducted from 10° to 90° with a scan speed of 2°/min. Temperature-dependent XRD measurements were conducted at the following temperatures: 30°C (room temperature), 100 °C, 200 °C, 400 °C, 600 °C, and 800 °C. The heating rate was sustained at 5 °C/min. Each temperature was held for 3 min, except for 800 °C, which was held for 1 h to ensure thermal stability. The measurements were carried out under ambient air conditions. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), CO-chemisorption, and H2-O2 pulse reaction were carried out using an Autochem III (Micromeritics). H2-TPR was carried out from 40 to 1000 °C at a constant ramp rate of 4.6 °C/min. Catalysts for CO-chemisorption were in-situ reduced in a 10 % H2/Ar composite at 800 °C for 3 h. After that CO gas was introduced, and Ni0 dispersion was calculated using a predetermined stoichiometric factor. The OSC of the catalyst was determined via an H2-O2 pulse reaction. Prior to oxygen pulsing, the sample underwent reduction in a 10 % H2/Ar condition at 400 °C for 1 h to eliminate mobile oxygen species. Oxygen uptake during subsequent 10 % O2/Ar pulses measured to calculate the OSC. 2.3 Catalytic reaction A catalytic performance test for DRM was conducted in a fixed-bed quartz micro-reactor with a 4 mm inner diameter, under atmospheric pressure. The reactor temperature was continuously controlled with a programmable temperature controller. The samples and SiO2 diluent were passed through a sieve to get particle sizes ranging from 53 ∼ 100 μm before use. The DRM was conducted under the subsequent conditions: 10 mg catalyst, 90 mg diluent, 33.3 % CO2, 33.4 % N2, and 33.3 % CH4, where N2 was used as an inert diluent gas. CO2, N2, and CH4 flows were precisely regulated using an independent mass flow controller. All applied catalysts used in reactions were reduced in-situ conditions at 800 °C under 10 % H2/N2 for 3 h. Then, the stability of the catalysts was confirmed at 800 °C and a GHSV of 900,000 mL/g∙h. The outlet gas from the reactor was condensed and subsequently passed through a Drierite to eliminate the remaining H2O. The gas was analyzed in real-time by micro gas chromatography (INFICON Micro GC Fusion). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The difference in the active metal loading amount directly impacts the dispersion of the catalyst, and it also influences the catalytic performance. We aimed to prepare the catalyst with the same Ni loading amount (15 wt%) to remove the effect of Ni loading amount, and concentrate on the influence of precipitant dropwise addition time. To confirm the actual loading amount of Ni, ICP-OES is employed. As shown in Table 2, all samples exhibit a uniform loading amount of Ni (around 16 wt%) regardless of the precipitant dropwise addition time. All catalysts exhibit a slightly higher Ni loading amount of approximately 16 wt% compared to the targeted 15 wt%. This discrepancy is attributed to the assumption made when calculating the Ni precursor amount that all Ce in the support will exist in the oxidation state of Ce4+. However, some of them will exist as Ce3+ due to the metastable nature of cerium [25]. For this reason, the measured Ni contents show relatively higher values. Table 2 presents the BET surface area of the catalysts, indicating that all samples exhibit comparable specific surface areas, varying from 74 to 84 m²/g. Fig. 1 illustrates the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of the catalysts, revealing a hysteresis loop with type IV isotherms. According to the IUPAC classification, a type IV isothermal hysteresis loop is typically observed when the sample possesses narrow and uniform cylindrical mesopores [26]. Moreover, BJH analysis result verified the formation of mesopores with pore diameters between 2 and 50 nm in all catalysts ( Fig. 2). As all the values estimated by BET analysis show similar results, it can be concluded that the dropwise addition time of precipitant does not significantly affect the surface areas and pore size distribution. When micropores are predominant in the catalyst, the diffusion of reactant molecules to the active sites can be hindered [27], and micropores are prone to blockage by deposited coke or active metal species during the reaction [28]. Conversely, an excessive presence of macropores may lead to a decline in the specific surface area and inefficient gas diffusion [29,30]. The existence of mesopores in the catalyst can enhance gas diffusion and improve the accessibility of reactants to active sites, simultaneously contributing to increased resistance against carbon deposition. The Raman analysis is performed to elucidate the structural variations caused by the defect formation in the local environment of CeO2 nanoparticles ( Fig. 3). All catalysts demonstrated a peak around 460 cm−1, which is assigned to the F2 g mode of the cubic fluorite CeO2 structure, corresponding to the symmetric stretching vibration of the Ce-O bond [31]. Among the results, the extent of peak shifting to the left was observed as the precipitant was dropwised more slowly. The peak shift implies the Ce-O lattice distortion resulting from nonstoichiometric variations, commonly influenced by dopant incorporation, crystallite size, or calcination conditions [32]. In this case, the phenomenon occurred due to the distortion of the CeO2 lattice, which is caused by the substitution of Ce4+ ions with Zr4+ ions [33]. The structural distortion within the CeO2 lattice is known to promote the formation of oxygen vacancies [34], which can potentially supply anchoring sites for the active metal [24]. The XPS spectra of the Ce 3d and O 1 s of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 after peak deconvolution, which provides information on the surface oxidation state concentration of Ce and O species. The numerical values are listed in Table 3. The Ce 3d region is typically divided into ten peaks [35]. The peaks pointed as v, v’’, v’’’, u, u’’, and u’’’ relate to Ce4+ species associated with the 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 states, whereas the peaks named v0, v’, u0, u’ are attributed to Ce3+ species in the same spin-orbit doublets. In the spectra, Ce3+ peaks are represented by red solid lines, Ce4+ peaks by gray dashed lines, and the black solid line indicates the baseline. The formation of Ce3+ species indicates the reduction of Ce4+, which is induced by the escape of oxygen atoms from the CeO2 lattice during the pre-reduction process [36]. As a result, the presence of Ce3+ reflects the availability of mobile oxygen and the existence of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. The O 1 s region deconvoluted into three distinct peaks [37]: lattice oxygen in CeO2 (OL), oxygen associated with structural vacancies (OV), and adsorbed oxygen species on the surface (OA). We have focused on the Ce3+ and OV, which reveals the OSC of the catalyst. It was observed that the binding energies of the oxygen peaks of XPS varied depending on the catalyst. The lower binding energies measured for NCZ 0 and NCZ 10, compared with those of NCZ 5 and NCZ 20, can be attributed to the dispersion of Ni0. When Ni0 is highly dispersed, the interfacial contact area between Ni0 and CeO2 increases, thereby promoting more active electron transfer [38,39]. This enhances the intrinsic activity of the Ni-[O]x-Ce interface, simultaneously lowering the electronic stability of the interface. As a result, the electron density increases, and the XPS peaks shift toward lower binding energies. Similar to the Raman spectra results, a longer precipitant dropwise addition time increased the concentration of both Ce3+ ions and oxygen vacancies. To further confirm the OSC of the catalyst, a H2-O2 pulse reaction is conducted (Table 3), which also shows a similar trend to the Raman and XPS results. As a result, it can be concluded that the longer precipitant dropwise addition time enhances the OSC of the catalyst. The formation of oxygen vacancies in the CeO2 lattice serves a critical role in enhancing catalyst performance by serving as anchoring sites for the active metal during calcination [24]. Moreover, increased OSC promotes redox cycling in the DRM and facilitates the re-oxidation of deposited carbon species [12], thereby improving both catalytic activity and stability. However, excessive generation of Ce3+ species during the pre-reduction step can lead to the ‘Ce covering effect’, whereby the active Ni0 sites are partially encapsulated by CeO2, resulting in a reduction of metal dispersion [16]. This is particularly important given that the pre-reduction step is unavoidable, as metallic Ni0 is the active phase in DRM [40]. Therefore, the optimization of OV and Ce3+ concentration is essential, while oxygen vacancies enhance metal dispersion and redox activity, but excessive Ce3+ formation may hinder active site accessibility. Notably, Ce3+-induced coverage may also strengthen the metal-support interaction (MSI) by partially encapsulating the Ni0, which can suppress sintering and enhance thermal stability [33]. Taken together, a balanced generation of oxygen vacancies and Ce3+ is required to simultaneously maximize Ni dispersion, redox capability, and MSI, while minimizing the detrimental ‘Ce covering effect’ to achieve optimal catalytic performance in DRM. XRD analysis is performed on reduced samples ( Fig. 5), and the crystallite size of Ni0 (the active phase) is calculated by the Scherrer equation based on the diffraction peak observed at 44.5°, which corresponds to the Ni0 (111) plane ( Table 4). The other major peaks originate from CeO2, ZrO2, and Ni0 were overlapped. The overlapping between the CeO2 and ZrO2 peaks indicates the formation of a CeO2-ZrO2 solid solution, which results from the substitution of Zr4+ ions into the CeO2 lattice due to the similar ionic radius of Ce4+ (0.97 Å) and Zr4+ (0.84 Å) [41]. To verify this phenomenon, the lattice parameter was calculated based on the information of the Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 (111) plane, and the results are summarized in Table 5. The lattice parameters of the Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 (111) plane are as follows: NCZ 0 (0.5377 nm), NCZ 5 (0.5382 nm), NCZ 10 (0.5377 nm), NCZ 20 (0.5392 nm). Compared with the lattice parameter of pristine CeO2 (0.541 nm) [42], a decrease in the lattice parameter was observed due to the substitution of Zr4+ ions into the CeO2 lattice, which induces the contraction of the support lattice. Interestingly, only the NCZ 20 catalyst exhibits the tetragonal phase of ZrO2 (t-ZrO2), while the other catalysts show the monoclinic ZrO2 (m-ZrO2). The t-ZrO2 has been reported to be favorably formed in an environment with an abundant amount of oxygen vacancies [43,44]. This result reveals that the NCZ 20 catalyst possesses the highest amount of oxygen vacancy among the prepared catalysts, which is well-matched with the aforementioned Raman, XPS, and H2-O2 pulse results. The dispersion of Ni0 in the catalysts is evaluated by CO-chemisorption. Table 4 shows the crystallite size and dispersion of Ni0, and these two parameters exhibit a clear relationship. The crystallite sizes of Ni0 are as follows: NCZ 0 (14.31 nm), NCZ 5 (18.97 nm), NCZ 10 (14.07 nm), NCZ 20 (17.17 nm). As the precipitant dropwise addition time increases from 0 (NCZ 0) to 5 min (NCZ 5), the crystallite size of Ni0 increases while the dispersion of Ni0 decreases (NCZ 0: 2.3 %, NCZ 5: 1.7 %) due to the favorable nuclei growth induced by a longer dropwise addition time (slower dropwise addition rate). This phenomenon represents the general correlation between nucleation theory and crystallite size. When the nucleation rate dominates over the growth rate of nuclei, smaller crystallites are formed [18]. The small crystallite size of Ni0 can strengthen the MSI and increase the number of active sites [8]. However, when the dropwise addition time increases to 10 min (NCZ 10), the Ni0 dispersion increases from 1.7 % to 2.3 %. This is due to the ‘oxygen vacancy anchoring-induced redistribution of Ni’, as the NCZ 10 catalyst possesses a suitable amount of oxygen vacancies. Ce4+ and Zr4+ ions possess comparable ionic radii, and the substitution of Zr4+ into the CeO2 lattice induces local lattice distortion. As the distortion leads to energetically unstable structures, it promotes the formation of mobile oxygen species and simultaneously oxygen vacancies [21,22]. These oxygen vacancies are electron-rich and chemically reactive sites that can serve as anchoring sites for Ni nanoparticles, thereby enhancing their dispersion [23]. In this work, ‘oxygen vacancy anchoring-induced redistribution’ refers to the enhanced dispersion and spatial rearrangement of Ni species during calcination, facilitated by surface oxygen vacancies that act as anchoring sites. The longer dropwise addition time induces proper growth of nuclei, resulting in a distortion of CeO2 that generates an appropriate number of oxygen vacancies, which act as anchoring sites for Ni. As a result, the dispersion of metallic Ni0 in the NCZ 10 catalyst exhibited the same value as the NCZ 0 catalyst (2.3 %). Finally, when the dropwise addition time has increased to 20 min (NCZ 20), the dispersion of Ni0 decreases to 2.0 %. This is due to the severe ‘Ce covering effect’ which favorably occurs in the oxygen vacancy-rich CeO2 system. A slow dropwise addition time leads to the growth of nuclei, resulting in the further distortion of CeO2. While an increased number of oxygen vacancies (in other words, increased concentration of Ce3+) facilitates the oxygen vacancy anchoring-induced redistribution of Ni, it also promotes excessive Ce3+ migration, leading to the ‘Ce covering effect’ and a subsequent decline in Ni dispersion. As a result, the NCZ 5 shows lower Ni0 dispersion compared to the NCZ 20. Although a pronounced Ce covering effect occurred in NCZ 20, the presence of abundant oxygen vacancies facilitated the redispersion of Ni. Consequently, the Ni0 dispersion increased in NCZ 10, but decreased again in NCZ 20. To validate the Ni0 dispersion obtained from CO-chemisorption, surface Ni species were further analyzed by XPS ( Fig. 6). The deconvoluted results show that the percentage of Ni0 on the surface is as follows: NCZ 0 (83.7 %), NCZ 5 (78.9 %), NCZ 10 (86.2 %), NCZ 20 (74.5 %). The majority of Ni species were identified in the metallic state, and their relative amounts exhibited a consistent trend with the dispersion and crystallite size of Ni0. TEM analysis was conducted to examine the physicochemical changes induced by varying the precipitant dropwise addition time, and the corresponding images are presented in Fig. 7. In addition, TEM was employed to cross-check the crystallite size of Ni0 calculated from XRD analysis, and the particle sizes estimated by TEM were found to be in close agreement. Interestingly, these results exhibited the same trend as both the Ni0 crystallite size obtained from XRD and the Ni0 dispersion measured by CO-chemisorption. For Ni0, lattice fringes corresponding to the (111) plane were observed with a d-spacing value of 2.03 Å [45], while for the Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 support, lattice fringes corresponding to the (111) plane were identified with a d-spacing value of 3.09 Å [46]. The smaller d-spacing of Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 compared to that of pristine CeO2 (3.12 Å) can be ascribed to lattice contraction induced by the substitution of Zr4+ ions into the CeO2 lattice [47], which was further confirmed by the lattice parameter values obtained from XRD analysis. Furthermore, we have observed from TEM results that the Ni is more covered by CeO2 as the precipitant dropwise addition time increases. Overall, it was shown that Ce3+ species generated under reducing conditions exhibited mobility, leading to the coverage of Ni by Ce species. This Ce covering effect became more pronounced as the precipitant dropwise addition time increased. Also, the extent of amorphous Ce species covering the Ni surface was found to be similar across all catalysts. To investigate the oxygen vacancy anchoring-induced redistribution of Ni, in-situ XRD analysis is conducted on the un-calcined (dried) NCZ 10 catalyst under air condition to simulate the calcination process ( Fig. 8). Similar to the aforementioned XRD result (Fig. 5), the in-situ XRD results also show overlapping diffraction peaks of CeO2 and ZrO2. Additionally, the peaks of Ni(OH)2 are observed from room temperature to 200 °C, while NiO peaks begin to appear above 400 °C without the Ni(OH)2 peak. During the calcination process under an oxidative atmosphere, exposure to high temperatures can lead to sintering of the metal species, resulting in more intense and sharper XRD peaks [48]. Therefore, excessive thermal exposure should be avoided. However, specific interactions between the active metal and the support during the calcination step can enhance MSI, which helps to prevent the sintering [24,32]. In this case, there was no remarkable growth in the NiO peak from 400 °C to 800 °C, indicating that the oxygen vacancy anchoring-induced redistribution of Ni occurs due to the appropriate amount of oxygen vacancies (generated during the calcination step), rather than NiO sintering. A certain degree of nuclei growth facilitated the substitution of Zr4+ ions into the CeO2 support, leading to the distortion of lattice. This structural distortion not only promoted the generation of abundant mobile oxygen but also created oxygen vacancies at the sites where oxygen atoms were removed, which subsequently acted as anchoring sites for Ni. Since the DRM proceeds via a redox mechanism, catalyst’s redox properties are a critical factor for enhancing both catalytic activity and stability. H2-TPR analysis was employed to examine the reduction behavior of the catalysts ( Fig. 9). According to the H2-TPR results, all catalysts exhibited four distinct peaks. The first peak corresponds to the reduction of the surface CeO2 [12,49]. Compared to pristine CeO2, the addition of Zr4+ (creating Ce0.8Zr0.2O2) can promote the reduction of CeO2 due to the enhanced OSC. In addition, surface Ce exhibits higher mobility and facilitates electron exchange more readily than bulk Ce. For the NCZ 0 catalyst, this peak is observed at a relatively high temperature (374 °C) due to the formation of small nuclei, which leads to a small crystallite size. Among NCZ 5–20, this peak shifts to higher temperatures, exhibiting a similar trend with the increase in OSC. As nuclei growth progresses, the substitution of Zr4+ ions into the CeO2 lattice occurs easier, leading to the formation of Ce3+ ions and oxygen vacancies, which indicate an enhanced reducibility of the catalyst, as evidenced by the peak of the NCZ 5 catalyst appearing at a lower temperature region compared to that of the NCZ 0 catalyst. However, this peak starts to shift to higher temperatures when the dropwise addition time increases to NCZ 20, indicating that enhanced nuclei growth led to the generation of a higher concentration of Ce3+ ions and oxygen vacancies. This suggests that hydrogen penetrates deeper into the bulk region beyond the surface, requiring higher temperatures for the reduction (H2 uptake). The second observed peak corresponds to the reduction of free NiO, indicating the reduction of NiO species located on the catalyst surface or weakly interacting with the support [12,49]. The attribution of the first peak to the reduction of CeO2 was evaluated based on the H2 consumption amount (indicated by the peak intensity); however, the intensity is too large to be reasonably ascribed solely to the reduction of surface CeO2. In line with the first reduction event, the NCZ 0 catalyst exhibited a peak at a relatively higher temperature, reflecting its lower reducibility. With an initial increase in nuclei growth, the peak shifts to a lower temperature. However, as the nuclei continue to grow, H2 penetrates deeper into the bulk region, leading to the reappearance of the peak at higher temperatures. The third peak is observed due to the reduction of complex NiO, which firmly interacts with the Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 support, playing a crucial role in the catalytic reaction. The strong metal-support interaction leads to increased reduction temperatures compared to free NiO, resulting from enhanced electronic and oxygen interactions between the active metal and the support. Ni particles with smaller crystallite sizes show stronger interactions with the support, which requires higher temperatures for reduction. In this process, an adequate amount of oxygen vacancies served as anchoring sites for Ni, whereas the overgrowth of nuclei leads to excessive Ce3+ migration, causing coverage of the active metal sites. The fourth peak reveals the reduction of bulk CeO2, which does not occur during the pre-reduction step due to the extremely high temperatures over 888 °C. It possesses low mobility and can only be reduced at high temperatures. 3.2 Catalytic performance Based on previous characterization results, we applied catalysts for the dry reforming of methane (DRM) reaction. Fig. 10 illustrates the CH4 conversion over 15 wt% Ni-Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 catalysts prepared with diverse precipitant dropwise addition times, evaluated at 800 °C for 10 h, a CH4:CO2:N2 ratio of 1:1:1, and a GHSV of 900,000 mL/g∙h. Among all the catalysts, the NCZ 10 catalyst demonstrated the highest conversion of CH4. The initial conversion showed the following order: NCZ 10 (94.6 %) > NCZ 5 (89.5 %) > NCZ 20 (87.9 %) > NCZ 0 (71.0 %). Interestingly, despite exhibiting the highest Ni0 dispersion (same with the NCZ 10 catalyst), the NCZ 0 catalyst showed the lowest initial conversion of CH4. This is due to the lowest OSC of the NCZ 0 catalyst. Despite having the highest Ni dispersion, NCZ 0 exhibited the lowest CH4 conversion, highlighting that OSC and redox capability may play a greater role than dispersion alone in DRM. The DRM is predominantly reported to follow the redox mechanism [50]. The redox properties of the catalyst not only facilitate this redox cycle but also contribute to the re-oxidation of carbon species generated during the reaction [51]. At the initial stage of the reaction, CH4 dissociation proceeds more readily than CO2, leading to the formation of surface carbon compounds. These carbon compounds deposit on active metal sites, reducing their dispersion and lowering the initial catalytic activity. These carbon radicals, which can be generated not only at the beginning but also during the reaction, tend to polymerize and deposit on the catalyst surface; however, the redox activity promotes their removal by converting them into CO or CO2, thereby preventing the fouling of active metal sites [51]. This indicates that, in the DRM, although the dispersion of Ni0 is a crucial factor for initial conversion, the oxygen storage capacity also plays a critical role in accelerating the redox cycle and facilitating the initiation of the reaction. From the perspective of stability, all catalysts maintained stable performance without deactivation over 10 h of reaction under harsh conditions (high gas hourly space velocity and reaction temperature). This is ascribed to the high OSC of the CeZrO2 support, which prevents the catalyst from carbon deposition caused by deactivation mechanisms such as methane decomposition and the Boudouard reaction. Additionally, oxygen vacancies generated by the distortion of the CeO2 lattice act as anchoring sites for Ni and inhibit the thermal sintering during the calcination, pre-reduction, and reaction processes. Therefore, it can be demonstrated that catalytic performance is significantly affected by both the dispersion of Ni0 and the oxygen storage capacity, which can be optimized by adjusting the precipitant dropwise addition time. 4 Conclusion This work highlights the critical role of precipitant dropwise addition time in modulating the structural and catalytic features of Ni (15 wt%)-C0.8Zr0.2O2 catalysts for dry reforming of methane, as illustrated in Fig. 11. The BET surface areas of all catalysts were detected similarly in the range of 74.3–84.3 m2/g. This result suggests that variations in precipitant dropwise addition time have a negligible effect on the surface area and porosity of the catalysts. Raman, XPS, and H2-O2 pulse reaction results simultaneously reveal that longer dropwise addition time of the precipitant increases the OSC of the catalyst. This trend is associated with the generation of Ce3+ and oxygen vacancies induced by lattice distortion in CeO2, stemming from substantial nuclei growth. Longer dropwise addition times promote further nuclei growth, ultimately leading to increased OSC. A high concentration of Ce3+ and OV is essential for enhancing the redox capability of the catalyst in the DRM by accelerating the redox cycle. However, a superfluous amount induces the coverage of active metal sites due to the Ce covering effect. This correlation was validated by calculating the crystallite size of Ni0 and the dispersion of Ni0, along with comparing the OSC-related values. In connection with the DRM results, a certain threshold of OSC is required to achieve enhanced catalytic performance through improved redox properties. During the nuclei growth process, oxygen vacancies formed by the distortion of the CeO2 lattice provide abundant OSC for the redox mechanism and also facilitate the oxygen vacancy anchoring-induced redistribution of Ni. However, exorbitant nuclei growth beyond the optimal level leads to an increased concentration of Ce3+, which can gradually reduce the dispersion of the active metal through the Ce covering effect. By integrating these findings, it was concluded that a controlled amount of Ce3+ and oxygen vacancies plays a key role in enhancing the Ni0 dispersion of the catalyst. This behavior is clearly illustrated in Fig. 11, where the balance between Ni0 dispersion and OSC is maximized at NCZ 10. Among the synthesized catalysts, the NCZ 10 sample, prepared with a dropwise addition time of 10 min, exhibited the optimal combination of high OSC and Ni dispersion, resulting in superior activity and stability in DRM. This study provides a comprehensive understanding of how precipitation kinetics influence metal-support interactions, offering a rational strategy for designing thermally stable and highly active DRM catalysts through structural tuning of the support interface, mainly induced by the oxygen vacancy-induced redistribution of Ni species. coredata.dc:description: Ni-Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 catalysts were synthesized via co-precipitation by varying the precipitant dropwise addition time (0, 5, 10, 20 min) to control nucleation and growth dynamics. This parameter critically influences the physicochemical properties of the catalysts, particularly the oxygen storage capacity (OSC) and Ni dispersion. Rapid dropwise addition (0, 5 min) resulted in insufficient lattice distortion, yielding fewer oxygen vacancies and lower oxygen storage capacity. Conversely, overly slow dropwise addition (20 min) led to excessive Ce3 + migration, promoting the Ce covering effect and suppressing Ni0 dispersion. An optimal dropwise addition time (10 min) revealed balanced characteristics with high OSC and superior Ni0 dispersion, leading to improved catalytic activity and stability in the dry reforming of methane. These findings demonstrate that fine-tuning of precipitation kinetics is crucial for optimizing Ce-Ni interfacial phenomena and maximizing catalytic performance.
